question: What is F5 BIG-IP and its main functions?
answer:
F5 BIG-IP is an application delivery controller (ADC) providing load balancing, traffic management, and security services.

Core functions: 1) Local Traffic Manager (LTM) - load balancing, 2) Global Traffic Manager (GTM) - DNS-based GSLB, 3) Application Security Manager (ASM) - WAF, 4) Access Policy Manager (APM) - authentication.

Key features: 1) Server load balancing, 2) SSL offloading, 3) Application acceleration, 4) Health monitoring, 5) iRules scripting.

Deployment modes: 1) Inline/routed, 2) One-arm, 3) DSR (Direct Server Return), 4) Reverse proxy.

question: Explain F5 virtual servers, pools, and pool members.
answer:
Virtual servers, pools, and pool members are fundamental F5 LTM objects for load balancing.

Virtual Server: 1) IP:Port combination, 2) Entry point for client traffic, 3) References pools and profiles, 4) Applies traffic policies.

Pool: 1) Group of backend servers, 2) Load balancing method, 3) Health monitors, 4) Priority groups.

Pool Members: 1) Individual servers in pool, 2) Node IP and service port, 3) Connection limits, 4) Priority and ratio.

Traffic flow: Client -> Virtual Server -> Pool -> Pool Member -> Backend Server.

question: What are F5 load balancing methods?
answer:
F5 provides multiple algorithms to distribute traffic across pool members.

Static methods: 1) Round Robin - sequential distribution, 2) Ratio - weighted distribution, 3) Priority Groups - failover based.

Dynamic methods: 1) Least Connections - fewest active connections, 2) Fastest - quickest response time, 3) Observed - combined metrics, 4) Predictive - trend analysis.

Advanced methods: 1) Least Sessions, 2) Weighted Least Connections, 3) Ratio Least Connections.

Selection criteria: 1) Application type, 2) Session requirements, 3) Server capacity, 4) Response time needs.

question: Explain F5 health monitors and their types.
answer:
Health monitors verify backend server availability and remove unhealthy servers from rotation.

Monitor types: 1) ICMP - basic ping, 2) TCP - port availability, 3) HTTP/HTTPS - application health, 4) Custom - application-specific.

HTTP monitor options: 1) Send string - request sent, 2) Receive string - expected response, 3) Receive disable - mark down, 4) Username/password.

Monitor parameters: 1) Interval - check frequency, 2) Timeout - response wait time, 3) Up interval - after recovery.

Best practices: 1) Use application-aware monitors, 2) Appropriate intervals, 3) Monitor actual service, 4) Multiple monitors for redundancy.

question: What are F5 profiles and their purpose?
answer:
Profiles define traffic behavior and optimizations applied to virtual servers.

Profile categories: 1) Protocol - TCP, UDP, FastL4, 2) Application - HTTP, FTP, DNS, 3) SSL - client/server SSL, 4) Persistence - session affinity, 5) Authentication.

TCP profiles: 1) Connection management, 2) Buffer sizes, 3) Timeout values, 4) Optimization settings.

HTTP profiles: 1) Request/response modification, 2) Compression, 3) Caching, 4) Cookie handling.

SSL profiles: 1) Certificate configuration, 2) Cipher suites, 3) Protocol versions, 4) Client/server SSL termination.

question: Explain F5 persistence (session affinity) methods.
answer:
Persistence ensures client sessions return to the same backend server for session continuity.

Persistence types: 1) Source Address - client IP, 2) Cookie - HTTP cookie, 3) SSL Session ID, 4) Universal - iRule based.

Cookie persistence modes: 1) Cookie Insert - F5 adds cookie, 2) Cookie Rewrite - modify existing, 3) Cookie Passive - use app cookie, 4) Cookie Hash - hash app cookie.

Parameters: 1) Timeout - persistence duration, 2) Mirror - HA sync, 3) Match across - services/virtuals.

Considerations: 1) Application requirements, 2) Client behavior, 3) NAT environments, 4) Performance impact.

question: What are F5 iRules and common use cases?
answer:
iRules are TCL-based scripts that provide granular traffic control on F5.

Common events: 1) CLIENT_ACCEPTED - connection start, 2) HTTP_REQUEST - HTTP request received, 3) HTTP_RESPONSE - response from server, 4) LB_SELECTED - pool member chosen.

Use cases: 1) Content switching, 2) Header manipulation, 3) URI rewriting, 4) Rate limiting, 5) Custom health checks.

Example - redirect: when HTTP_REQUEST { if { [HTTP::uri] starts_with "/old" } { HTTP::redirect "https://[HTTP::host]/new" } }

Best practices: 1) Minimize iRule complexity, 2) Use built-in features first, 3) Test thoroughly, 4) Monitor performance impact.

question: Explain F5 SSL offloading and re-encryption.
answer:
SSL offloading terminates SSL at F5, optionally re-encrypting to backend servers.

SSL offloading: 1) Client SSL profile on virtual, 2) F5 decrypts traffic, 3) Backend receives HTTP, 4) Reduces server load.

SSL re-encryption: 1) Both client and server SSL profiles, 2) F5 decrypts from client, 3) Re-encrypts to server, 4) End-to-end encryption.

Certificate management: 1) Import certificates, 2) Create SSL profiles, 3) Certificate chains, 4) Key management.

Considerations: 1) Cipher suite selection, 2) Protocol versions, 3) Performance impact, 4) Compliance requirements.

question: What is F5 SNAT and when is it used?
answer:
SNAT (Secure NAT) translates source addresses for traffic passing through F5.

SNAT types: 1) Automap - use self IP, 2) SNAT Pool - pool of addresses, 3) None - no translation.

When needed: 1) One-arm deployment, 2) Servers not using F5 as gateway, 3) Asymmetric routing prevention, 4) Source IP hiding.

Considerations: 1) Port exhaustion (64K per IP), 2) Server logging (loses client IP), 3) X-Forwarded-For header, 4) SNAT pool sizing.

Configuration: 1) Create SNAT pool, 2) Assign to virtual server, 3) Or use Automap, 4) Configure XFF for logging.

question: Explain F5 high availability configurations.
answer:
F5 HA ensures continuous availability through device redundancy and failover.

HA modes: 1) Active/Standby - one active, 2) Active/Active - both process traffic, 3) Device groups - multiple devices.

Failover triggers: 1) Hardware failure, 2) Network failure, 3) Manual failover, 4) Health monitor failure.

Sync components: 1) Configuration sync, 2) Persistence mirroring, 3) Connection mirroring.

Network requirements: 1) HA VLAN, 2) Failover addresses, 3) Mirroring addresses, 4) Self IPs.

question: What is F5 OneConnect and connection pooling?
answer:
OneConnect optimizes backend connections by reusing server-side connections for multiple clients.

How it works: 1) Maintains pool of server connections, 2) Reuses connections for new requests, 3) Reduces server TCP overhead, 4) Improves response time.

Benefits: 1) Reduced server connections, 2) Lower latency, 3) Better server efficiency, 4) Handles connection surges.

Configuration: 1) OneConnect profile, 2) Source mask settings, 3) Maximum size, 4) Idle timeout.

Use cases: 1) HTTP keep-alive environments, 2) High-traffic applications, 3) Limited server connections, 4) API gateways.

question: Explain F5 Global Traffic Manager (GTM/DNS).
answer:
GTM provides intelligent DNS-based global server load balancing across data centers.

Key features: 1) GSLB - global load balancing, 2) DNS resolution, 3) Health monitoring, 4) Disaster recovery.

GTM objects: 1) Data centers, 2) Servers (BIG-IPs/hosts), 3) Virtual servers, 4) Wide IPs, 5) Pools.

Load balancing methods: 1) Round Robin, 2) Ratio, 3) Topology - location based, 4) QoS - quality metrics.

Topology records: 1) Region-based steering, 2) ISP preference, 3) Continent/country rules.

question: What is F5 Application Security Manager (ASM)?
answer:
ASM is F5's web application firewall (WAF) providing Layer 7 security.

Protection types: 1) OWASP Top 10, 2) SQL injection, 3) Cross-site scripting, 4) Parameter tampering, 5) Bot protection.

Policy modes: 1) Negative security - block known bad, 2) Positive security - allow known good, 3) Hybrid - combination.

Learning modes: 1) Automatic learning, 2) Manual policy building, 3) Guided configuration, 4) Policy import.

Signature updates: 1) Automatic updates, 2) Attack signature database, 3) Custom signatures.

question: Explain F5 Access Policy Manager (APM).
answer:
APM provides identity-aware access control and VPN services.

Key features: 1) VPN (SSL/IPsec), 2) Single sign-on (SSO), 3) Federation (SAML), 4) Multi-factor authentication, 5) Access control.

Access policy: 1) Visual Policy Editor, 2) Authentication actions, 3) Authorization checks, 4) Resource assignment.

VPN types: 1) Network Access - full tunnel, 2) Web Application - portal access, 3) App Tunnel - specific apps.

Integration: 1) Active Directory, 2) LDAP, 3) RADIUS, 4) SAML IdP/SP, 5) OAuth/OIDC.

question: How do you troubleshoot F5 load balancing issues?
answer:
Systematic troubleshooting identifies connectivity and traffic distribution problems.

Troubleshooting tools: 1) Statistics - virtual/pool stats, 2) Logs - LTM logs, 3) tcpdump - packet capture, 4) TMM logs - traffic manager.

Common issues: 1) Pool members down, 2) Health monitor failures, 3) Persistence issues, 4) SSL errors.

Verification commands: 1) tmsh show ltm virtual, 2) tmsh show ltm pool, 3) tmsh show ltm node, 4) tmsh show sys connection.

Packet flow analysis: 1) Client to virtual, 2) Virtual to pool member, 3) Member response, 4) Response to client.

question: What is F5 traffic policy vs iRules?
answer:
Traffic policies provide GUI-based traffic manipulation without writing iRules code.

Local Traffic Policy: 1) Conditions and actions, 2) Rule-based logic, 3) GUI configuration, 4) Easier management.

iRules: 1) TCL scripting, 2) More flexibility, 3) Complex logic, 4) Higher learning curve.

When to use policies: 1) Simple conditions, 2) Standard actions, 3) Ease of management, 4) Non-programmers.

When to use iRules: 1) Complex logic, 2) Variable manipulation, 3) Custom functions, 4) Event-driven actions.

question: Explain F5 device service clustering (DSC).
answer:
DSC enables multiple F5 devices to work together for HA and scalability.

DSC components: 1) Device trust - authentication, 2) Device groups - sync groups, 3) Traffic groups - active/standby.

Sync-Failover group: 1) Config synchronization, 2) Automatic failover, 3) Connection mirroring.

Sync-Only group: 1) Configuration sync only, 2) No failover, 3) Multiple data centers.

Traffic groups: 1) Floating IPs, 2) Active device ownership, 3) Failover order, 4) HA status.

question: What is F5 HTTP compression and caching?
answer:
Compression and caching optimize content delivery and reduce bandwidth.

HTTP compression: 1) Gzip compression, 2) Content-type based, 3) Minimum size threshold, 4) CPU vs bandwidth trade-off.

Web acceleration (caching): 1) Static content caching, 2) Cache policies, 3) Cache invalidation, 4) Memory allocation.

Configuration: 1) HTTP compression profile, 2) Web acceleration profile, 3) Assign to virtual server.

Considerations: 1) CPU utilization, 2) Content types, 3) Cache hit ratio, 4) Memory sizing.

question: Explain F5 TMSH command line interface.
answer:
TMSH (Traffic Management Shell) is F5's command line interface for configuration and monitoring.

TMSH modes: 1) Interactive mode, 2) Single command mode, 3) Script mode.

Common commands: 1) list - show configuration, 2) show - show statistics, 3) create - create objects, 4) modify - change objects, 5) delete - remove objects.

Examples: 1) tmsh list ltm virtual, 2) tmsh show ltm pool [name], 3) tmsh create ltm node [name] address [ip], 4) tmsh save sys config.

Transaction mode: 1) Begin transaction, 2) Make changes, 3) Commit or rollback.

question: What is F5 iApps and application templates?
answer:
iApps are application-centric templates that simplify complex configurations.

Components: 1) Template - defines questions and logic, 2) Application Service - deployed instance, 3) APL - scripting language.

Benefits: 1) Simplified deployment, 2) Consistent configuration, 3) Best practices built-in, 4) Self-service portal.

Built-in templates: 1) f5.http, 2) f5.https, 3) f5.microsoft_exchange, 4) f5.oracle_database.

Custom templates: 1) Create custom templates, 2) Define variables, 3) Include configuration, 4) Deploy as service.

question: Explain F5 rate limiting and connection limits.
answer:
Rate limiting controls request rates to protect backend servers and prevent abuse.

Rate limiting methods: 1) Connection rate limit, 2) Request rate limit (iRule), 3) Bandwidth rate limit.

Connection limits: 1) Virtual server connection limit, 2) Pool member connection limit, 3) Node connection limit.

Configuration: 1) Rate class profiles, 2) Per-virtual limits, 3) iRules for advanced control.

Use cases: 1) DoS protection, 2) API rate limiting, 3) Fair usage, 4) Capacity protection.

question: What is F5 NAT vs SNAT vs Automap?
answer:
F5 provides different NAT options for various deployment scenarios.

NAT: 1) Destination NAT, 2) Virtual server address translation, 3) Client connects to VIP.

SNAT: 1) Source NAT, 2) Translates client source IP, 3) Uses SNAT pool addresses.

Automap: 1) Automatic SNAT, 2) Uses self IP of egress VLAN, 3) Simplest configuration.

When to use: 1) Automap - simple deployments, 2) SNAT pool - high volume, port exhaustion concerns, 3) No SNAT - when F5 is default gateway.

question: Explain F5 SSL forward proxy.
answer:
SSL forward proxy enables inspection of outbound SSL/TLS traffic.

How it works: 1) Intercept client SSL requests, 2) Present dynamic certificate to client, 3) Establish SSL to destination, 4) Inspect decrypted traffic.

Requirements: 1) CA certificate for signing, 2) Client trust of CA, 3) Forward proxy profile, 4) Destination filtering.

Use cases: 1) Outbound security inspection, 2) Data loss prevention, 3) Malware detection, 4) Compliance.

Bypass options: 1) Category bypass, 2) Destination bypass, 3) Client certificate sites.

question: What is F5 Analytics and AVR?
answer:
Application Visibility and Reporting (AVR) provides detailed analytics for applications.

AVR capabilities: 1) Real-time dashboards, 2) Historical reporting, 3) Transaction analysis, 4) Performance metrics.

Metrics collected: 1) Response times, 2) Throughput, 3) Page load times, 4) Server latency, 5) Client location.

Configuration: 1) Enable analytics profile, 2) Attach to virtual server, 3) Configure collection settings, 4) Set retention period.

Use cases: 1) Performance monitoring, 2) Capacity planning, 3) Troubleshooting, 4) SLA compliance.

question: Explain F5 AS3 declarative automation.
answer:
AS3 (Application Services 3) is F5's declarative API for configuration automation.

AS3 concepts: 1) Declarative model - describe desired state, 2) JSON schema, 3) Tenant-based, 4) Idempotent operations.

Declaration structure: 1) Class - object type, 2) Tenant - logical partition, 3) Application - service grouping, 4) Properties - configuration.

Benefits: 1) Infrastructure as code, 2) Version control, 3) CI/CD integration, 4) Consistent deployments.

Tools: 1) AS3 extension, 2) REST API, 3) Terraform provider, 4) Ansible modules.

question: What is F5 priority group activation?
answer:
Priority groups control traffic distribution based on pool member availability.

How it works: 1) Members assigned priority (0-65535), 2) Higher priority served first, 3) Lower priority activated when needed.

Activation threshold: 1) Minimum available members, 2) When threshold not met, 3) Next priority group activates.

Use cases: 1) Primary/backup servers, 2) DR failover, 3) Capacity tiers, 4) Cost optimization.

Configuration: 1) Set member priority, 2) Configure minimum active members, 3) Monitor group health.

question: Explain F5 virtual server types.
answer:
F5 supports different virtual server types optimized for specific traffic patterns.

Standard: 1) Full proxy, 2) Complete traffic management, 3) All profiles available.

Performance (Layer 4): 1) Packet-based forwarding, 2) Limited profiles, 3) High throughput.

Forwarding (IP): 1) Packet forwarding, 2) No port translation, 3) Simple routing.

Forwarding (Layer 2): 1) MAC-based forwarding, 2) Transparent mode, 3) Bridge-like behavior.

Reject: 1) Sends reset/unreachable, 2) Block specific traffic.

question: What is F5 connection mirroring?
answer:
Connection mirroring replicates connection state to standby device for stateful failover.

Mirrored data: 1) Connection table, 2) Persistence records, 3) SSL session IDs.

Configuration: 1) Enable mirroring on virtual, 2) Configure mirror addresses, 3) HA VLAN for mirror traffic.

Considerations: 1) Bandwidth overhead, 2) Mirror VLAN sizing, 3) Not all connections mirrored, 4) UDP connections not stateful.

When to use: 1) Long-lived connections, 2) Critical applications, 3) Zero connection loss required.

question: Explain F5 partitions and route domains.
answer:
Partitions and route domains provide multi-tenancy on F5 devices.

Partitions: 1) Administrative separation, 2) Object isolation, 3) Role-based access, 4) Configuration separation.

Route domains: 1) Network isolation, 2) Overlapping IP support, 3) Separate routing tables, 4) VLAN assignment.

Use cases: 1) Multi-tenant hosting, 2) Departmental separation, 3) Development/production, 4) Overlapping IP addresses.

Configuration: 1) Create partition, 2) Create route domain, 3) Assign VLANs, 4) Create objects in partition.

question: What are F5 best practices for production deployment?
answer:
Best practices ensure reliable, secure, and performant F5 deployments.

Architecture: 1) HA pair minimum, 2) Proper sizing, 3) Network redundancy, 4) Separate management network.

Security: 1) Change default passwords, 2) Use HTTPS management, 3) RBAC configuration, 4) Regular updates.

Configuration: 1) Use profiles appropriately, 2) Application-aware monitors, 3) Appropriate timeouts, 4) Connection limits.

Operations: 1) Regular backups, 2) Change management, 3) Monitoring and alerting, 4) Documentation.
